page.title: 01LAND WEST OF BUTLEY RIVER
page.content: This is an area of river and salt-marsh, with re-claimed marshes behind grass banks. The higher ground, no-where rising above 79 ft, is poor sandy soil, largely devoted to Forestry Commission pines. there are two small villages, Boyton and Capel St. Andrew, and although there are some holiday cottages and commuters, most people work on local farms, or are retired farm workers. Corn crops, including rye, are grown as well as potatoes, sugar-beet, carrots and onions. Beef cattle graze along the river banks. Pheasants and partridges are plentiful and there are deer in the forests. Estuary birds flourish, including the avocet, and there are oyster beds in the river. The Suffolk Heritage Coastal Walk follows the river wall and crosses Burrow Hill, once a tidal island, and the site of
